articles.headline: Macron’s Win Is Also a Blow to Viktor Orban’s Nationalist Crusade
articles.snippet: The Hungarian leader had cast his own victory as the start of a nationalist wave in Europe — one that Marine Le Pen would have joined. Instead, Mr. Macron’s victory in France is a win for the European Union’s approach.
articles.abstract: The Hungarian leader had cast his own victory as the start of a nationalist wave in Europe — one that Marine Le Pen would have joined. Instead, Mr. Macron’s victory in France is a win for the European Union’s approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — There were sighs of relief throughout the European Union after President Emmanuel Macron beat back a serious challenge in France from the populist far-right champion Marine Le Pen.

articles.headline: With Deal for Twitter, Musk Lands a Prize and Pledges Fewer Limits
articles.snippet: The world’s richest man succeeded in a bid to acquire the influential social networking service, which he has said he wants to take private.
articles.abstract: The world’s richest man succeeded in a bid to acquire the influential social networking service, which he has said he wants to take private.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk struck a deal on Monday to buy Twitter for roughly $44 billion, in a victory by the world’s richest man to take over the influential social network frequented by world leaders, celebrities and cultural trendsetters.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: Emboldened by Ukraine’s Grit, U.S. Wants to See Russia Weakened
articles.snippet: Hours after the American secretaries of defense and state met with Ukraine’s president in Kyiv, Russia hit at least five Ukrainian railway stations in rocket attacks.
articles.abstract: Hours after the American secretaries of defense and state met with Ukraine’s president in Kyiv, Russia hit at least five Ukrainian railway stations in rocket attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: KRAKOW, Poland — The United States toughened its messaging on the Ukraine war on Monday, saying the American aim was not just to thwart the Russian invasion but also to weaken Russia so it could no longer carry out such military aggression anywhere.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora, John Ismay and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: Behind Austin’s Call for a ‘Weakened’ Russia, Hints of a Shift
articles.snippet: The United States is edging toward a dynamic that pits Washington more directly against Moscow, and one that U.S. officials see as likely to play out for years.
articles.abstract: The United States is edging toward a dynamic that pits Washington more directly against Moscow, and one that U.S. officials see as likely to play out for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III declared Monday at the end of a stealth visit to Ukraine that America’s goal is to see Russia so “weakened” that it would no longer have the power to invade a neighboring state, he was acknowledging a transformation of the conflict, from a battle over control of Ukraine to one that pits Washington more directly against Moscow.

articles.headline: Buying Twitter, Elon Musk Will Face Reality of His Free-Speech Talk
articles.snippet: Tech’s big shots have learned again and again that free speech isn’t so simple. What happens when Mr. Musk owns Twitter?
articles.abstract: Tech’s big shots have learned again and again that free speech isn’t so simple. What happens when Mr. Musk owns Twitter?
articles.lead_paragraph: A decade ago, Twitter executives, including the chief executive, Dick Costolo, declared that the social media site was the “free-speech wing of the free-speech party.” The stance meant Twitter would defend people’s ability to post whatever they wished and be heard by the world.

articles.headline: ‘I Just Want to Help’: Amid Chaos, Shanghai Residents Band Together
articles.snippet: As the authorities in China’s biggest city fight to stamp out an Omicron outbreak, neighbors are turning to one another for support.
articles.abstract: As the authorities in China’s biggest city fight to stamp out an Omicron outbreak, neighbors are turning to one another for support.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four days into a coronavirus lockdown in her Shanghai neighborhood, Ding Tingting began to worry about the old man who lived alone in the apartment below her. She knocked on his door and found that his food supply was dwindling and that he didn’t know how to go online to buy more.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson, Amy Chang Chien and Isabelle Qian

articles.headline: Nuclear Power Could Help Europe Cut Its Russia Ties, but Not for Years
articles.snippet: The projects, which some European countries are pushing to end their reliance on Russia’s energy, face delays in coming online.
articles.abstract: The projects, which some European countries are pushing to end their reliance on Russia’s energy, face delays in coming online.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — On the windswept coast of Flamanville, an industrial city in northwest France facing the choppy waters of the English Channel, a soaring concrete dome houses one of the world’s most powerful nuclear reactors.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: New Details Underscore House G.O.P. Role in Jan. 6 Planning
articles.snippet: A court filing and newly disclosed text messages provide additional evidence of how closely some fervent pro-Trump lawmakers worked with the White House on efforts to overturn the election.
articles.abstract: A court filing and newly disclosed text messages provide additional evidence of how closely some fervent pro-Trump lawmakers worked with the White House on efforts to overturn the election.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was less than two weeks before President Donald J. Trump’s staunchest allies in Congress would have what they saw as their last chance to overturn the 2020 election, and Representative Scott Perry, Republican of Pennsylvania, was growing anxious.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: Why U.S. Oil Companies Aren’t Riding to Europe’s Rescue
articles.snippet: American energy production has only inched up because executives fear that oil and gas prices won’t stay high.
articles.abstract: American energy production has only inched up because executives fear that oil and gas prices won’t stay high.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Oil and gasoline prices are climbing. Energy company profits are surging. President Biden, who came into office promising to reduce the use of fossil fuels, has effectively joined the “drill, baby, drill” chorus. Europe would love to end its dependence on Russia.
